CatDescriptText: Miss Nila Velar, receptionist, Butler and Arthur E. Schmidt, postal relations man, Pleasant Hills, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, January 21, 1961, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think students are learning as much under the modern methods of teaching in public schools than students did years ago under the 3 R's (the old teaching method)?" Miss Nila Velar's answer reads: "I have a 12 year-old brother and some of the things he comes home with are ridiculous.  For instance the other day he brought home a little story, a jivy story about hep cats.  I asked him where he got it and he said in class during part of his rest period.  I don't think this is the exception but goes on all the time.  The '3-R' teaching method was better."  Arthur E. Schmidt's answer reads: "I don't think they learn as well.  They are learning more things.  The scope is larger, but they are not learning the little things, like how to break down a word to spell it.  I wouldn't advocate returning to the old method, but I think they should case up in the speed-up of the methods... My older child, under the old method, was able to retain learning, but the younger children, after about two months, don't remember what they have been taught."
